citation.article-title: Amendment of the genus Saccharothrix Labeda et al. 1984 and descriptions of Saccharothrix espanaesis sp. nov., Saccharothrix cryophilis sp. nov, and Saccharothrix mutabilis comb. nov.

p.s: Saccharothrix cryophilis (cry. o. phil’ is. L. adj. cryophilis, cold loving, referring to the low permissive temperature range for growth).
Pale yellow substrate mycelium is produced on most media.
White to yellowish white aerial mycelium is produced, particularly on inorganic salts-starch agar or glycerol-asparagine agar.
Esculin, tyrosine, and urea are hydrolyzed or decomposed, but adenine, allantoin, casein, hippurate, hypoxanthine, starch, and xanthine are not.
Acetate, DL-lactate, DL-malate, oxalate, propionate, and succinate are assimilated; benzoate, citrate, mucate, and DL-tartrate are not assimilated.

Acid is produced from D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, glycerol, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose, D-mannose, and trehalose; no acid is produced from adonitol, L-arabinose, cellobiose, dextrin, dulcitol, meso-erythritol, melibiose, L-rhamnose, salicin, D-sorbitol, sucrose, D-xylose, α-methyl-D-glucoside, and β-methyl-D-xyloside; and acid production from glycerol and raffinose is variable.
Growth occurs in the presence of 4% NaCl but not in the presence of 5% NaCl.
The temperature range for growth is 10 to 33°C.
The guanine-pluscytosine content of the DNA is 71.4 mol% (thermal denaturation midpoint method).
The type strain of S. cryophilis is strain NRRL B-16238 (= IF0 14475 = Y.
